title: Barrett's Esophagus with High-Grade Dysplasia
diagnosis_topic: Premalignant change in distal esophagus with high-grade dysplasia
setup_script: A 48-year-old man with chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease undergoes surveillance endoscopy, which reveals a segment of salmon-colored mucosa. Biopsies show high-grade dysplasia.

dynamic_flow.reply: Histology reviewed by two independent pathologists confirming high-grade dysplasia without invasive carcinoma.

Endoscopic eradication therapy including endoscopic mucosal resection (EMR) for visible lesions followed by radiofrequency ablation (RFA) versus esophagectomy for extensive disease or multifocal high-grade dysplasia.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident evaluates patient's surgical risk
dynamic_flow.reply: Low comorbidity; thus endoscopic therapy preferred due to lower morbidity.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident performs EMR on nodular areas
dynamic_flow.reply: Resection specimen sent for pathology to rule out invasive cancer; RFA performed on remaining Barrett's segment.
Every 3 months in first year then every 6 months for the next year to detect recurrence.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident prescribes high-dose proton pump inhibitors
dynamic_flow.reply: Essential to heal mucosa and prevent acid exposure; consider fundoplication if refractory.
Risk of progression to adenocarcinoma increases substantially.
Ivor Lewis or transhiatal approach based on surgeon experience; reserved for extensive or recurrent dysplasia.
Weight loss, smoking cessation, avoidance of alcohol and triggering foods.
Eradication does not affect Barrett's but may influence gastric cancer risk.
Chronic acid exposure leads to intestinal metaplasia and dysplasia, increasing cancer risk.
Importance of adherence to surveillance schedule and acid suppression therapy.

critical_decision_points: Confirmation of high-grade dysplasia by expert pathology
Selection of endoscopic eradication therapy versus surgical esophagectomy
Importance of acid suppression and lifestyle modification
Close surveillance to detect recurrence or progression
Patient education on risk of progression and need for adherence
